title-group.article-title: Justice et injustice ordinaire sur les lieux de travail d'après les audiences prud'homales (1806-1866)

abstract.p: L'article présente les premiers résultats d'une recherche en cours, menée d'après les archives de huit Conseils de prud'hommes, depuis leurs origines. A travers l'interaction aux audiences est étudiée l'interaction sur les lieux de travail. L'exploration d'un domaine inconnu jusqu'à maintenant met en cause la vision historique des rapports patrons-ouvriers, depuis le Premier Empire jusqu'au Second, qu'il s'agisse du droit ou des pratiques usuelles. Afin de reconstruire un ordre industriel, la voie conciliatrice s'imposa comme la solution la plus efficace, face à l'impuissance des voies répressives. L'article analyse comment les conflits pouvaient éclater et se régler, comment se sont établies des sortes de législations locales du travail, en dissidence avec le droit national français, puis comment ce modèle a été remis en cause, à la fin du Second Empire, lorsque des patrons prétendirent s'instaurer seuls juges sur le lieu de travail. /// The article gives the first results of an ongoing research through eight "Conseil de prud'hommes" archives. The interactions during the hearings give a way to understand the interactions on the workplace. The exploration of a yet unknown world questions the common historical view of labour relations from the First to the Second Empire, whatever a matter of law or of common practices. The individual conciliator way was thrusted by evidence of efficiency against the repressive way, in order to rebuild an industrial order. The article analyses how the conflicts could break out and be settled, how sets of local rules were laid down and generated a discrepancy between prud'hommes' customs and the national law. And how this model was destabilized at the end of the Second Empire, when employers claimed to be instituted as unique judges on the workplace. seuls juges sur le lieu de travail. /// The article gives the first results of an ongoing research through eight "Conseil de prud'hommes'" archives. The interactions during the hearings give a way to understand the interactions on the workplace. The exploration of a yert unknown world questions the common historial view of labour relations from the First to the Second Empire, whatever a matter of law or of common practices. The individual conciliator way was thrusted by evidence of efficiency against the repressive way, in order to rebuild an idustrial order. The article analyses how the conflicts could break out and be settled, how sets of local rules were laid down and generated a discrepancy between prud'hommes' customs and the national law. And how this model was destabilized at the end of the Second Empire, when employers claimed to be instituted as unique judges on the workplace.
